-- | Permanently deletes an Firewall Manager policy.
module Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeletePolicy</a> smart constructor.
data DeletePolicy
DeletePolicy' :: Maybe Bool -> Text -> DeletePolicy

-- | If <tt>True</tt>, the request performs cleanup according to the policy
--   type.
--   
--   For WAF and Shield Advanced policies, the cleanup does the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Deletes rule groups created by Firewall Manager</li>
--   <li>Removes web ACLs from in-scope resources</li>
--   <li>Deletes web ACLs that contain no rules or rule groups</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For security group policies, the cleanup does the following for each
--   security group in the policy:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Disassociates the security group from in-scope resources</li>
--   <li>Deletes the security group if it was created through Firewall
--   Manager and if it's no longer associated with any resources through
--   another policy</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   After the cleanup, in-scope resources are no longer protected by web
--   ACLs in this policy. Protection of out-of-scope resources remains
--   unchanged. Scope is determined by tags that you create and accounts
--   that you associate with the policy. When creating the policy, if you
--   specify that only resources in specific accounts or with specific tags
--   are in scope of the policy, those accounts and resources are handled
--   by the policy. All others are out of scope. If you don't specify tags
--   or accounts, all resources are in scope.
[$sel:deleteAllPolicyResources:DeletePolicy'] :: DeletePolicy -> Maybe Bool

-- | The ID of the policy that you want to delete. You can retrieve this ID
--   from <tt>PutPolicy</tt> and <tt>ListPolicies</tt>.
[$sel:policyId:DeletePolicy'] :: DeletePolicy -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>DeletePolicy</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:deleteAllPolicyResources:DeletePolicy'</a>,
--   <a>deletePolicy_deleteAllPolicyResources</a> - If <tt>True</tt>, the
--   request performs cleanup according to the policy type.
--   
--   For WAF and Shield Advanced policies, the cleanup does the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Deletes rule groups created by Firewall Manager</li>
--   <li>Removes web ACLs from in-scope resources</li>
--   <li>Deletes web ACLs that contain no rules or rule groups</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For security group policies, the cleanup does the following for each
--   security group in the policy:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Disassociates the security group from in-scope resources</li>
--   <li>Deletes the security group if it was created through Firewall
--   Manager and if it's no longer associated with any resources through
--   another policy</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   After the cleanup, in-scope resources are no longer protected by web
--   ACLs in this policy. Protection of out-of-scope resources remains
--   unchanged. Scope is determined by tags that you create and accounts
--   that you associate with the policy. When creating the policy, if you
--   specify that only resources in specific accounts or with specific tags
--   are in scope of the policy, those accounts and resources are handled
--   by the policy. All others are out of scope. If you don't specify tags
--   or accounts, all resources are in scope.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyId:DeletePolicy'</a>, <a>deletePolicy_policyId</a> - The
--   ID of the policy that you want to delete. You can retrieve this ID
--   from <tt>PutPolicy</tt> and <tt>ListPolicies</tt>.
newDeletePolicy :: Text -> DeletePolicy

-- | If <tt>True</tt>, the request performs cleanup according to the policy
--   type.
--   
--   For WAF and Shield Advanced policies, the cleanup does the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Deletes rule groups created by Firewall Manager</li>
--   <li>Removes web ACLs from in-scope resources</li>
--   <li>Deletes web ACLs that contain no rules or rule groups</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For security group policies, the cleanup does the following for each
--   security group in the policy:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Disassociates the security group from in-scope resources</li>
--   <li>Deletes the security group if it was created through Firewall
--   Manager and if it's no longer associated with any resources through
--   another policy</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   After the cleanup, in-scope resources are no longer protected by web
--   ACLs in this policy. Protection of out-of-scope resources remains
--   unchanged. Scope is determined by tags that you create and accounts
--   that you associate with the policy. When creating the policy, if you
--   specify that only resources in specific accounts or with specific tags
--   are in scope of the policy, those accounts and resources are handled
--   by the policy. All others are out of scope. If you don't specify tags
--   or accounts, all resources are in scope.
deletePolicy_deleteAllPolicyResources :: Lens' DeletePolicy (Maybe Bool)

-- | The ID of the policy that you want to delete. You can retrieve this ID
--   from <tt>PutPolicy</tt> and <tt>ListPolicies</tt>.
deletePolicy_policyId :: Lens' DeletePolicy Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeletePolicyResponse</a> smart constructor.
data DeletePolicyResponse
DeletePolicyResponse' :: DeletePolicyResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>DeletePolicyResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newDeletePolicyResponse :: DeletePolicyResponse
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicyResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicyResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicyResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicyResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicyResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.FMS.DeletePolicy.DeletePolicy


-- | Deletes an Firewall Manager association with the IAM role and the
--   Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) topic that is used to record
--   Firewall Manager SNS logs.
module Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeleteNotificationChannel</a> smart constructor.

-- | Create a value of <a>DeleteNotificationChannel</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newDeleteNotificationChannel :: DeleteNotificationChannel

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeleteNotificationChannelResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.

-- | Create a value of <a>DeleteNotificationChannelResponse</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel.DeleteNotificationChannel
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel.DeleteNotificationChannel

instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel.DeleteNotificationChannel
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel.DeleteNotificationChannelResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel.DeleteNotificationChannelResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel.DeleteNotificationChannelResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel.DeleteNotificationChannelResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel.DeleteNotificationChannel
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel.DeleteNotificationChannelResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.FMS.DeleteNotificationChannel.DeleteNotificationChannel

--   and <tt>GetAppsList</tt>.

--   <tt>GetAppsList</tt>.

-- | The ID of the applications list that you want to delete. You can

-- | Sets the Firewall Manager administrator account. The account must be a
--   member of the organization in Organizations whose resources you want
--   to protect. Firewall Manager sets the permissions that allow the
--   account to administer your Firewall Manager policies.
--   
--   The account that you associate with Firewall Manager is called the
--   Firewall Manager administrator account.
module Network.AWS.FMS.AssociateAdminAccount

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAssociateAdminAccount</a> smart constructor.
data AssociateAdminAccount
AssociateAdminAccount' :: Text -> AssociateAdminAccount

-- | The Amazon Web Services account ID to associate with Firewall Manager
--   as the Firewall Manager administrator account. This must be an
--   Organizations member account. For more information about
--   Organizations, see <a>Managing the Amazon Web Services Accounts in
--   Your Organization</a>.
[$sel:adminAccount:AssociateAdminAccount'] :: AssociateAdminAccount -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>AssociateAdminAccount</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:adminAccount:AssociateAdminAccount'</a>,
--   <a>associateAdminAccount_adminAccount</a> - The Amazon Web Services
--   account ID to associate with Firewall Manager as the Firewall Manager
--   administrator account. This must be an Organizations member account.
--   For more information about Organizations, see <a>Managing the Amazon
--   Web Services Accounts in Your Organization</a>.
newAssociateAdminAccount :: Text -> AssociateAdminAccount

-- | The Amazon Web Services account ID to associate with Firewall Manager
--   as the Firewall Manager administrator account. This must be an
--   Organizations member account. For more information about
--   Organizations, see <a>Managing the Amazon Web Services Accounts in
--   Your Organization</a>.
associateAdminAccount_adminAccount :: Lens' AssociateAdminAccount Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAssociateAdminAccountResponse</a> smart constructor.
data AssociateAdminAccountResponse

--   optional fields omitted.

--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

-- | Removes one or more tags from an Amazon Web Services resource.
module Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUntagResource</a> smart constructor.
data UntagResource
UntagResource' :: Text -> [Text] -> UntagResource

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource to return tags for. The
--   Firewall Manager resources that support tagging are policies,
--   applications lists, and protocols lists.
[$sel:resourceArn:UntagResource'] :: UntagResource -> Text

-- | The keys of the tags to remove from the resource.
[$sel:tagKeys:UntagResource'] :: UntagResource -> [Text]

-- | Create a value of <a>UntagResource</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceArn:UntagResource'</a>,
--   <a>untagResource_resourceArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource to return tags for. The Firewall Manager resources that
--   support tagging are policies, applications lists, and protocols lists.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tagKeys:UntagResource'</a>, <a>untagResource_tagKeys</a> - The
--   keys of the tags to remove from the resource.
newUntagResource :: Text -> UntagResource

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource to return tags for. The
--   Firewall Manager resources that support tagging are policies,
--   applications lists, and protocols lists.
untagResource_resourceArn :: Lens' UntagResource Text

-- | The keys of the tags to remove from the resource.
untagResource_tagKeys :: Lens' UntagResource [Text]

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUntagResourceResponse</a> smart constructor.
data UntagResourceResponse
UntagResourceResponse' :: Int -> UntagResourceResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:UntagResourceResponse'] :: UntagResourceResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>UntagResourceResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:UntagResourceResponse'</a>,
--   <a>untagResourceResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
newUntagResourceResponse :: Int -> UntagResourceResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
untagResourceResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' UntagResourceResponse Int
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResourceResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResourceResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResourceResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResourceResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResourceResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.FMS.UntagResource.UntagResource


module Network.AWS.FMS.Lens

-- | If you specify a value for <tt>MaxResults</tt> and you have more
--   <tt>PolicySummary</tt> objects than the number that you specify for
--   <tt>MaxResults</tt>, Firewall Manager returns a <tt>NextToken</tt>
--   value in the response that allows you to list another group of
--   <tt>PolicySummary</tt> objects. For the second and subsequent
--   <tt>ListPolicies</tt> requests, specify the value of
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> from the previous response to get information about
--   another batch of <tt>PolicySummary</tt> objects.
listPolicies_nextToken :: Lens' ListPolicies (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies the number of <tt>PolicySummary</tt> objects that you want
--   Firewall Manager to return for this request. If you have more
--   <tt>PolicySummary</tt> objects than the number that you specify for
--   <tt>MaxResults</tt>, the response includes a <tt>NextToken</tt> value
--   that you can use to get another batch of <tt>PolicySummary</tt>
--   objects.
listPolicies_maxResults :: Lens' ListPolicies (Maybe Natural)

-- | If you have more <tt>PolicySummary</tt> objects than the number that
--   you specified for <tt>MaxResults</tt> in the request, the response
--   includes a <tt>NextToken</tt> value. To list more
--   <tt>PolicySummary</tt> objects, submit another <tt>ListPolicies</tt>
--   request, and specify the <tt>NextToken</tt> value from the response in
--   the <tt>NextToken</tt> value in the next request.
listPoliciesResponse_nextToken :: Lens' ListPoliciesResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | An array of <tt>PolicySummary</tt> objects.
listPoliciesResponse_policyList :: Lens' ListPoliciesResponse (Maybe [PolicySummary])

-- | The response's http status code.
listPoliciesResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' ListPoliciesResponse Int

-- | If <tt>True</tt>, the request performs cleanup according to the policy
--   type.
--   
--   For WAF and Shield Advanced policies, the cleanup does the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Deletes rule groups created by Firewall Manager</li>
--   <li>Removes web ACLs from in-scope resources</li>
--   <li>Deletes web ACLs that contain no rules or rule groups</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For security group policies, the cleanup does the following for each
--   security group in the policy:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Disassociates the security group from in-scope resources</li>
--   <li>Deletes the security group if it was created through Firewall
--   Manager and if it's no longer associated with any resources through
--   another policy</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   After the cleanup, in-scope resources are no longer protected by web
--   ACLs in this policy. Protection of out-of-scope resources remains
--   unchanged. Scope is determined by tags that you create and accounts
--   that you associate with the policy. When creating the policy, if you
--   specify that only resources in specific accounts or with specific tags
--   are in scope of the policy, those accounts and resources are handled
--   by the policy. All others are out of scope. If you don't specify tags
--   or accounts, all resources are in scope.
deletePolicy_deleteAllPolicyResources :: Lens' DeletePolicy (Maybe Bool)

-- | The ID of the policy that you want to delete. You can retrieve this ID
--   from <tt>PutPolicy</tt> and <tt>ListPolicies</tt>.
deletePolicy_policyId :: Lens' DeletePolicy Text

-- | If you specify a value for <tt>MaxResults</tt> and you have more
--   objects than the number that you specify for <tt>MaxResults</tt>,
--   Firewall Manager returns a <tt>NextToken</tt> value in the response,
--   which you can use to retrieve another group of objects. For the second
--   and subsequent <tt>GetProtectionStatus</tt> requests, specify the
--   value of <tt>NextToken</tt> from the previous response to get
--   information about another batch of objects.
getProtectionStatus_nextToken :: Lens' GetProtectionStatus (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies the number of objects that you want Firewall Manager to
--   return for this request. If you have more objects than the number that
--   you specify for <tt>MaxResults</tt>, the response includes a
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> value that you can use to get another batch of
--   objects.
getProtectionStatus_maxResults :: Lens' GetProtectionStatus (Maybe Natural)

-- | The start of the time period to query for the attacks. This is a
--   <tt>timestamp</tt> type. The request syntax listing indicates a
--   <tt>number</tt> type because the default used by Firewall Manager is
--   Unix time in seconds. However, any valid <tt>timestamp</tt> format is
--   allowed.
getProtectionStatus_startTime :: Lens' GetProtectionStatus (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The end of the time period to query for the attacks. This is a
--   <tt>timestamp</tt> type. The request syntax listing indicates a
--   <tt>number</tt> type because the default used by Firewall Manager is
--   Unix time in seconds. However, any valid <tt>timestamp</tt> format is
--   allowed.
getProtectionStatus_endTime :: Lens' GetProtectionStatus (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The Amazon Web Services account that is in scope of the policy that
--   you want to get the details for.
getProtectionStatus_memberAccountId :: Lens' GetProtectionStatus (Maybe Text)

-- | The ID of the policy for which you want to get the attack information.
getProtectionStatus_policyId :: Lens' GetProtectionStatus Text

-- | If you have more objects than the number that you specified for
--   <tt>MaxResults</tt> in the request, the response includes a
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> value. To list more objects, submit another
--   <tt>GetProtectionStatus</tt> request, and specify the
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> value from the response in the <tt>NextToken</tt>
--   value in the next request.
--   
--   Amazon Web Services SDKs provide auto-pagination that identify
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> in a response and make subsequent request calls
--   automatically on your behalf. However, this feature is not supported
--   by <tt>GetProtectionStatus</tt>. You must submit subsequent requests
--   with <tt>NextToken</tt> using your own processes.
getProtectionStatusResponse_nextToken :: Lens' GetProtectionStatusResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The ID of the Firewall Manager administrator account for this policy.
getProtectionStatusResponse_adminAccountId :: Lens' GetProtectionStatusResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | Details about the attack, including the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Attack type</li>
--   <li>Account ID</li>
--   <li>ARN of the resource attacked</li>
--   <li>Start time of the attack</li>
--   <li>End time of the attack (ongoing attacks will not have an end
--   time)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The details are in JSON format.
getProtectionStatusResponse_data :: Lens' GetProtectionStatusResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The service type that is protected by the policy. Currently, this is
--   always <tt>SHIELD_ADVANCED</tt>.
getProtectionStatusResponse_serviceType :: Lens' GetProtectionStatusResponse (Maybe SecurityServiceType)

-- | The response's http status code.
getProtectionStatusResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' GetProtectionStatusResponse Int

-- | If you specify a value for <tt>MaxResults</tt> in your list request,
--   and you have more objects than the maximum, Firewall Manager returns
--   this token in the response. For all but the first request, you provide
--   the token returned by the prior request in the request parameters, to
--   retrieve the next batch of objects.
listAppsLists_nextToken :: Lens' ListAppsLists (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies whether the lists to retrieve are default lists owned by
--   Firewall Manager.
listAppsLists_defaultLists :: Lens' ListAppsLists (Maybe Bool)

-- | The maximum number of objects that you want Firewall Manager to return
--   for this request. If more objects are available, in the response,
--   Firewall Manager provides a <tt>NextToken</tt> value that you can use
--   in a subsequent call to get the next batch of objects.
--   
--   If you don't specify this, Firewall Manager returns all available
--   objects.
listAppsLists_maxResults :: Lens' ListAppsLists Natural

-- | If you specify a value for <tt>MaxResults</tt> in your list request,
--   and you have more objects than the maximum, Firewall Manager returns
--   this token in the response. You can use this token in subsequent
--   requests to retrieve the next batch of objects.
listAppsListsResponse_nextToken :: Lens' ListAppsListsResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | An array of <tt>AppsListDataSummary</tt> objects.
listAppsListsResponse_appsLists :: Lens' ListAppsListsResponse (Maybe [AppsListDataSummary])

-- | The response's http status code.
listAppsListsResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' ListAppsListsResponse Int

-- | The tags associated with the resource.
putAppsList_tagList :: Lens' PutAppsList (Maybe [Tag])

-- | The details of the Firewall Manager applications list to be created.
putAppsList_appsList :: Lens' PutAppsList AppsListData

-- | The details of the Firewall Manager applications list.
putAppsListResponse_appsList :: Lens' PutAppsListResponse (Maybe AppsListData)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the applications list.
putAppsListResponse_appsListArn :: Lens' PutAppsListResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The response's http status code.
putAppsListResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' PutAppsListResponse Int

-- | Specifies whether the list to retrieve is a default list owned by
--   Firewall Manager.
getAppsList_defaultList :: Lens' GetAppsList (Maybe Bool)

-- | The ID of the Firewall Manager applications list that you want the
--   details for.
getAppsList_listId :: Lens' GetAppsList Text

-- | Information about the specified Firewall Manager applications list.
getAppsListResponse_appsList :: Lens' GetAppsListResponse (Maybe AppsListData)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the applications list.
getAppsListResponse_appsListArn :: Lens' GetAppsListResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The response's http status code.
getAppsListResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' GetAppsListResponse Int

-- | If you specify a value for <tt>MaxResults</tt> in your list request,
--   and you have more objects than the maximum, Firewall Manager returns
--   this token in the response. For all but the first request, you provide
--   the token returned by the prior request in the request parameters, to
--   retrieve the next batch of objects.
listProtocolsLists_nextToken :: Lens' ListProtocolsLists (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies whether the lists to retrieve are default lists owned by
--   Firewall Manager.
listProtocolsLists_defaultLists :: Lens' ListProtocolsLists (Maybe Bool)

-- | The maximum number of objects that you want Firewall Manager to return
--   for this request. If more objects are available, in the response,
--   Firewall Manager provides a <tt>NextToken</tt> value that you can use
--   in a subsequent call to get the next batch of objects.
--   
--   If you don't specify this, Firewall Manager returns all available
--   objects.
listProtocolsLists_maxResults :: Lens' ListProtocolsLists Natural

-- | An array of <tt>ProtocolsListDataSummary</tt> objects.
listProtocolsListsResponse_protocolsLists :: Lens' ListProtocolsListsResponse (Maybe [ProtocolsListDataSummary])

-- | If you specify a value for <tt>MaxResults</tt> in your list request,
--   and you have more objects than the maximum, Firewall Manager returns
--   this token in the response. You can use this token in subsequent
--   requests to retrieve the next batch of objects.
listProtocolsListsResponse_nextToken :: Lens' ListProtocolsListsResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The response's http status code.
listProtocolsListsResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' ListProtocolsListsResponse Int

-- | The tags associated with the resource.
putProtocolsList_tagList :: Lens' PutProtocolsList (Maybe [Tag])

-- | The details of the Firewall Manager protocols list to be created.
putProtocolsList_protocolsList :: Lens' PutProtocolsList ProtocolsListData

-- | The details of the Firewall Manager protocols list.
putProtocolsListResponse_protocolsList :: Lens' PutProtocolsListResponse (Maybe ProtocolsListData)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the protocols list.
putProtocolsListResponse_protocolsListArn :: Lens' PutProtocolsListResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The response's http status code.
putProtocolsListResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' PutProtocolsListResponse Int

-- | If you specify a value for <tt>MaxResults</tt> and you have more
--   <tt>PolicyComplianceStatus</tt> objects than the number that you
--   specify for <tt>MaxResults</tt>, Firewall Manager returns a
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> value in the response that allows you to list
--   another group of <tt>PolicyComplianceStatus</tt> objects. For the
--   second and subsequent <tt>ListComplianceStatus</tt> requests, specify
--   the value of <tt>NextToken</tt> from the previous response to get
--   information about another batch of <tt>PolicyComplianceStatus</tt>
--   objects.
listComplianceStatus_nextToken :: Lens' ListComplianceStatus (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies the number of <tt>PolicyComplianceStatus</tt> objects that
--   you want Firewall Manager to return for this request. If you have more
--   <tt>PolicyComplianceStatus</tt> objects than the number that you
--   specify for <tt>MaxResults</tt>, the response includes a
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> value that you can use to get another batch of
--   <tt>PolicyComplianceStatus</tt> objects.
listComplianceStatus_maxResults :: Lens' ListComplianceStatus (Maybe Natural)

-- | The ID of the Firewall Manager policy that you want the details for.
listComplianceStatus_policyId :: Lens' ListComplianceStatus Text

-- | If you have more <tt>PolicyComplianceStatus</tt> objects than the
--   number that you specified for <tt>MaxResults</tt> in the request, the
--   response includes a <tt>NextToken</tt> value. To list more
--   <tt>PolicyComplianceStatus</tt> objects, submit another
--   <tt>ListComplianceStatus</tt> request, and specify the
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> value from the response in the <tt>NextToken</tt>
--   value in the next request.
listComplianceStatusResponse_nextToken :: Lens' ListComplianceStatusResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | An array of <tt>PolicyComplianceStatus</tt> objects.
listComplianceStatusResponse_policyComplianceStatusList :: Lens' ListComplianceStatusResponse (Maybe [PolicyComplianceStatus])

-- | The response's http status code.
listComplianceStatusResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' ListComplianceStatusResponse Int

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource to return tags for. The
--   Firewall Manager resources that support tagging are policies,
--   applications lists, and protocols lists.
untagResource_resourceArn :: Lens' UntagResource Text

-- | The keys of the tags to remove from the resource.
untagResource_tagKeys :: Lens' UntagResource [Text]

-- | The response's http status code.
untagResourceResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' UntagResourceResponse Int

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource to return tags for. The
--   Firewall Manager resources that support tagging are policies,
--   applications lists, and protocols lists.
tagResource_resourceArn :: Lens' TagResource Text

-- | The tags to add to the resource.
tagResource_tagList :: Lens' TagResource [Tag]

-- | The response's http status code.
tagResourceResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' TagResourceResponse Int

--   SNS.

--   Your Organization</a>.

--   account IDs than the number that you specify for <tt>MaxResults</tt>,
--   Firewall Manager returns a <tt>NextToken</tt> value in the response
--   that allows you to list another group of IDs. For the second and
--   subsequent <tt>ListMemberAccountsRequest</tt> requests, specify the
--   value of <tt>NextToken</tt> from the previous response to get
--   information about another batch of member account IDs.

--   Manager policy.

-- | The number of resources that are noncompliant with the specified
--   policy. For WAF and Shield Advanced policies, a resource is considered
--   noncompliant if it is not associated with the policy. For security
--   group policies, a resource is considered noncompliant if it doesn't
--   comply with the rules of the policy and remediation is disabled or not
--   possible.

-- | Information about the VPC ID.

-- | The resource ID of the current route table that's associated with the

networkFirewallMissingExpectedRTViolation_currentRouteTable :: Lens' NetworkFirewallMissingExpectedRTViolation (Maybe Text)

--   firewall policy.

--   stateless rule groups.

--   default actions settings.

--   Manager policy.
partialMatch_reference :: Lens' PartialMatch (Maybe Text)

-- | An array of <tt>ResourceTag</tt> objects.
policy_resourceTags :: Lens' Policy (Maybe [ResourceTag])

-- | An array of <tt>ResourceType</tt> objects. Use this only to specify
--   multiple resource types. To specify a single resource type, use
--   <tt>ResourceType</tt>.
policy_resourceTypeList :: Lens' Policy (Maybe [Text])

-- | A unique identifier for each update to the policy. When issuing a
--   <tt>PutPolicy</tt> request, the <tt>PolicyUpdateToken</tt> in the
--   request must match the <tt>PolicyUpdateToken</tt> of the current
--   policy version. To get the <tt>PolicyUpdateToken</tt> of the current
--   policy version, use a <tt>GetPolicy</tt> request.
policy_policyUpdateToken :: Lens' Policy (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies the Amazon Web Services account IDs and Organizations
--   organizational units (OUs) to include in the policy. Specifying an OU
--   is the equivalent of specifying all accounts in the OU and in any of
--   its child OUs, including any child OUs and accounts that are added at
--   a later time.
--   
--   You can specify inclusions or exclusions, but not both. If you specify
--   an <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, Firewall Manager applies the policy to all
--   accounts specified by the <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, and does not evaluate
--   any <tt>ExcludeMap</tt> specifications. If you do not specify an
--   <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, then Firewall Manager applies the policy to all
--   accounts except for those specified by the <tt>ExcludeMap</tt>.
--   
--   You can specify account IDs, OUs, or a combination:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specify account IDs by setting the key to <tt>ACCOUNT</tt>. For
--   example, the following is a valid map: <tt>{ACCOUNT : [accountID1,
--   accountID2]}</tt>.</li>
--   <li>Specify OUs by setting the key to <tt>ORG_UNIT</tt>. For example,
--   the following is a valid map: <tt>{ORG_UNIT : [ouid111,
--   ouid112]}</tt>.</li>
--   <li>Specify accounts and OUs together in a single map, separated with
--   a comma. For example, the following is a valid map: <tt>{ACCOUNT :
--   [accountID1, accountID2], ORG_UNIT : [ouid111,
--   ouid112]}</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
policy_includeMap :: Lens' Policy (Maybe (HashMap CustomerPolicyScopeIdType [Text]))

-- | The ID of the Firewall Manager policy.
policy_policyId :: Lens' Policy (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies the Amazon Web Services account IDs and Organizations
--   organizational units (OUs) to exclude from the policy. Specifying an
--   OU is the equivalent of specifying all accounts in the OU and in any
--   of its child OUs, including any child OUs and accounts that are added
--   at a later time.
--   
--   You can specify inclusions or exclusions, but not both. If you specify
--   an <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, Firewall Manager applies the policy to all
--   accounts specified by the <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, and does not evaluate
--   any <tt>ExcludeMap</tt> specifications. If you do not specify an
--   <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, then Firewall Manager applies the policy to all
--   accounts except for those specified by the <tt>ExcludeMap</tt>.
--   
--   You can specify account IDs, OUs, or a combination:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specify account IDs by setting the key to <tt>ACCOUNT</tt>. For
--   example, the following is a valid map: <tt>{ACCOUNT : [accountID1,
--   accountID2]}</tt>.</li>
--   <li>Specify OUs by setting the key to <tt>ORG_UNIT</tt>. For example,
--   the following is a valid map: <tt>{ORG_UNIT : [ouid111,
--   ouid112]}</tt>.</li>
--   <li>Specify accounts and OUs together in a single map, separated with
--   a comma. For example, the following is a valid map: <tt>{ACCOUNT :
--   [accountID1, accountID2], ORG_UNIT : [ouid111,
--   ouid112]}</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
policy_excludeMap :: Lens' Policy (Maybe (HashMap CustomerPolicyScopeIdType [Text]))

-- | Indicates whether Firewall Manager should delete Firewall Manager
--   managed resources, such as web ACLs and security groups, when they are
--   not in use by the Firewall Manager policy. By default, Firewall
--   Manager doesn't delete unused Firewall Manager managed resources. This
--   option is not available for Shield Advanced or WAF Classic policies.
policy_deleteUnusedFMManagedResources :: Lens' Policy (Maybe Bool)

-- | The name of the Firewall Manager policy.
policy_policyName :: Lens' Policy Text

-- | Details about the security service that is being used to protect the
--   resources.
policy_securityServicePolicyData :: Lens' Policy SecurityServicePolicyData

-- | The type of resource protected by or in scope of the policy. This is
--   in the format shown in the <a>Amazon Web Services Resource Types
--   Reference</a>. To apply this policy to multiple resource types,
--   specify a resource type of <tt>ResourceTypeList</tt> and then specify
--   the resource types in a <tt>ResourceTypeList</tt>.
--   
--   For WAF and Shield Advanced, example resource types include
--   <tt>AWS::ElasticLoadBalancingV2::LoadBalancer</tt> and
--   <tt>AWS::CloudFront::Distribution</tt>. For a security group common
--   policy, valid values are <tt>AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface</tt> and
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>. For a security group content audit
--   policy, valid values are <tt>AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup</tt>,
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface</tt>, and <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>.
--   For a security group usage audit policy, the value is
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup</tt>. For an Network Firewall policy or
--   DNS Firewall policy, the value is <tt>AWS::EC2::VPC</tt>.
policy_resourceType :: Lens' Policy Text

-- | If set to <tt>True</tt>, resources with the tags that are specified in
--   the <tt>ResourceTag</tt> array are not in scope of the policy. If set
--   to <tt>False</tt>, and the <tt>ResourceTag</tt> array is not null,
--   only resources with the specified tags are in scope of the policy.
policy_excludeResourceTags :: Lens' Policy Bool

-- | Indicates if the policy should be automatically applied to new
--   resources.
policy_remediationEnabled :: Lens' Policy Bool

-- | An array of resources that aren't protected by the WAF or Shield
--   Advanced policy or that aren't in compliance with the security group
--   policy.
policyComplianceDetail_violators :: Lens' PolicyComplianceDetail (Maybe [ComplianceViolator])

-- | The Amazon Web Services account that created the Firewall Manager
--   policy.
policyComplianceDetail_policyOwner :: Lens' PolicyComplianceDetail (Maybe Text)

-- | The Amazon Web Services account ID.
policyComplianceDetail_memberAccount :: Lens' PolicyComplianceDetail (Maybe Text)

--   Manager policy.

--   and the error message received that indicates the problem with the
--   service.
policyComplianceDetail_issueInfoMap :: Lens' PolicyComplianceDetail (Maybe (HashMap DependentServiceName Text))

policyComplianceDetail_policyId :: Lens' PolicyComplianceDetail (Maybe Text)

--   considered out of date.
policyComplianceDetail_expiredAt :: Lens' PolicyComplianceDetail (Maybe UTCTime)

--   policy.

policyComplianceStatus_evaluationResults :: Lens' PolicyComplianceStatus (Maybe [EvaluationResult])

--   and the error message received that indicates the problem with the
--   service.
policyComplianceStatus_issueInfoMap :: Lens' PolicyComplianceStatus (Maybe (HashMap DependentServiceName Text))

policyComplianceStatus_policyId :: Lens' PolicyComplianceStatus (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of the specified policy.
policySummary_policyName :: Lens' PolicySummary (Maybe Text)

-- | The service that the policy is using to protect the resources. This
--   specifies the type of policy that is created, either an WAF policy, a
--   Shield Advanced policy, or a security group policy.
policySummary_securityServiceType :: Lens' PolicySummary (Maybe SecurityServiceType)

-- | The type of resource protected by or in scope of the policy. This is
--   in the format shown in the <a>Amazon Web Services Resource Types
--   Reference</a>. For WAF and Shield Advanced, examples include
--   <tt>AWS::ElasticLoadBalancingV2::LoadBalancer</tt> and
--   <tt>AWS::CloudFront::Distribution</tt>. For a security group common
--   policy, valid values are <tt>AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface</tt> and
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>. For a security group content audit
--   policy, valid values are <tt>AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup</tt>,
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface</tt>, and <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>.
--   For a security group usage audit policy, the value is
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup</tt>. For an Network Firewall policy or
--   DNS Firewall policy, the value is <tt>AWS::EC2::VPC</tt>.
policySummary_resourceType :: Lens' PolicySummary (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates if the policy should be automatically applied to new
--   resources.
policySummary_remediationEnabled :: Lens' PolicySummary (Maybe Bool)

policySummary_policyArn :: Lens' PolicySummary (Maybe Text)

policySummary_policyId :: Lens' PolicySummary (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates whether Firewall Manager should delete Firewall Manager
--   managed resources, such as web ACLs and security groups, when they are
--   not in use by the Firewall Manager policy. By default, Firewall
--   Manager doesn't delete unused Firewall Manager managed resources. This
--   option is not available for Shield Advanced or WAF Classic policies.
policySummary_deleteUnusedFMManagedResources :: Lens' PolicySummary (Maybe Bool)

-- | Violation detail for a DNS Firewall policy that indicates that the VPC
--   reached the limit for associated DNS Firewall rule groups. Firewall
--   Manager tried to associate another rule group with the VPC and failed.

--   group that Firewall Manager tried to associate with a VPC is already
--   associated with the VPC and can't be associated again.

--   subnet is not associated with the expected Firewall Manager managed

--   subnet has no Firewall Manager managed firewall in its VPC.

resourceViolation_awsVPCSecurityGroupViolation :: Lens' ResourceViolation (Maybe AwsVPCSecurityGroupViolation)

-- | Violation detail for an Network Firewall policy that indicates that a
--   firewall policy in an individual account has been modified in a way
--   that makes it noncompliant. For example, the individual account owner
--   might have deleted a rule group, changed the priority of a stateless
--   rule group, or changed a policy default action.
resourceViolation_networkFirewallPolicyModifiedViolation :: Lens' ResourceViolation (Maybe NetworkFirewallPolicyModifiedViolation)

--   group that Firewall Manager tried to associate with a VPC has the same
--   priority as a rule group that's already associated.
resourceViolation_dnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation :: Lens' ResourceViolation (Maybe DnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation)

route_destinationType :: Lens' Route (Maybe DestinationType)

route_targetType :: Lens' Route (Maybe TargetType)

route_destination :: Lens' Route (Maybe Text)

-- | The route's target.
route_target :: Lens' Route (Maybe Text)

-- | The remediation action that will be performed.
securityGroupRemediationAction_remediationActionType :: Lens' SecurityGroupRemediationAction (Maybe RemediationActionType)

-- | The final state of the rule specified in the <tt>ViolationTarget</tt>
--   after it is remediated.
securityGroupRemediationAction_remediationResult :: Lens' SecurityGroupRemediationAction (Maybe SecurityGroupRuleDescription)

-- | Indicates if the current action is the default action.
securityGroupRemediationAction_isDefaultAction :: Lens' SecurityGroupRemediationAction (Maybe Bool)

-- | Brief description of the action that will be performed.
securityGroupRemediationAction_description :: Lens' SecurityGroupRemediationAction (Maybe Text)

-- | The start of the port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an
--   ICMP/ICMPv6 type number. A value of <tt>-1</tt> indicates all
--   ICMP/ICMPv6 types.
securityGroupRuleDescription_fromPort :: Lens' SecurityGroupRuleDescription (Maybe Natural)

-- | The IPv4 ranges for the security group rule.
securityGroupRuleDescription_iPV4Range :: Lens' SecurityGroupRuleDescription (Maybe Text)

-- | The ID of the prefix list for the security group rule.
securityGroupRuleDescription_prefixListId :: Lens' SecurityGroupRuleDescription (Maybe Text)

-- | The IP protocol name (<tt>tcp</tt>, <tt>udp</tt>, <tt>icmp</tt>,
--   <tt>icmpv6</tt>) or number.
securityGroupRuleDescription_protocol :: Lens' SecurityGroupRuleDescription (Maybe Text)

-- | The IPv6 ranges for the security group rule.
securityGroupRuleDescription_iPV6Range :: Lens' SecurityGroupRuleDescription (Maybe Text)

-- | The end of the port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an
--   ICMP/ICMPv6 code. A value of <tt>-1</tt> indicates all ICMP/ICMPv6
--   codes.
securityGroupRuleDescription_toPort :: Lens' SecurityGroupRuleDescription (Maybe Natural)

-- | Details about the service that are specific to the service type, in
--   JSON format. For service type <tt>SHIELD_ADVANCED</tt>, this is an
--   empty string.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>DNS_FIREWALL</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"DNS_FIREWALL\",\"preProcessRuleGroups\":[{\"ruleGroupId\":\"rslvr-frg-1\",\"priority\":10}],\"postProcessRuleGroups\":[{\"ruleGroupId\":\"rslvr-frg-2\",\"priority\":9911}]}"</pre>Valid
--   values for <tt>preProcessRuleGroups</tt> are between 1 and 99. Valid
--   values for <tt>postProcessRuleGroups</tt> are between 9901 and
--   10000.</li>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>NETWORK_FIREWALL</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"NETWORK_FIREWALL\",\"networkFirewallStatelessRuleGroupReferences\":[{\"resourceARN\":\"arn:aws:network-firewall:us-west-1:1234567891011:stateless-rulegroup/rulegroup2\",\"priority\":10}],\"networkFirewallStatelessDefaultActions\":[\"aws:pass\",\"custom1\"],\"networkFirewallStatelessFragmentDefaultActions\":[\"custom2\",\"aws:pass\"],\"networkFirewallStatelessCustomActions\":[{\"actionName\":\"custom1\",\"actionDefinition\":{\"publishMetricAction\":{\"dimensions\":[{\"value\":\"dimension1\"}]}}},{\"actionName\":\"custom2\",\"actionDefinition\":{\"publishMetricAction\":{\"dimensions\":[{\"value\":\"dimension2\"}]}}}],\"networkFirewallStatefulRuleGroupReferences\":[{\"resourceARN\":\"arn:aws:network-firewall:us-west-1:1234567891011:stateful-rulegroup/rulegroup1\"}],\"networkFirewallOrchestrationConfig\":{\"singleFirewallEndpointPerVPC\":true,\"allowedIPV4CidrList\":[\"10.24.34.0/28\"]}
--   }"</pre></li>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>WAFV2</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"WAFV2\",\"preProcessRuleGroups\":[{\"ruleGroupArn\":null,\"overrideAction\":{\"type\":\"NONE\"},\"managedRuleGroupIdentifier\":{\"version\":null,\"vendorName\":\"AWS\",\"managedRuleGroupName\":\"AWSManagedRulesAmazonIpReputationList\"},\"ruleGroupType\":\"ManagedRuleGroup\",\"excludeRules\":[{\"name\":\"NoUserAgent_HEADER\"}]}],\"postProcessRuleGroups\":[],\"defaultAction\":{\"type\":\"ALLOW\"},\"overrideCustomerWebACLAssociation\":false,\"loggingConfiguration\":{\"logDestinationConfigs\":[\"arn:aws:firehose:us-west-2:12345678912:deliverystream/aws-waf-logs-fms-admin-destination\"],\"redactedFields\":[{\"redactedFieldType\":\"SingleHeader\",\"redactedFieldValue\":\"Cookies\"},{\"redactedFieldType\":\"Method\"}]}}"</pre>In
--   the <tt>loggingConfiguration</tt>, you can specify one
--   <tt>logDestinationConfigs</tt>, you can optionally provide up to 20
--   <tt>redactedFields</tt>, and the <tt>RedactedFieldType</tt> must be
--   one of <tt>URI</tt>, <tt>QUERY_STRING</tt>, <tt>HEADER</tt>, or
--   <tt>METHOD</tt>.</li>
--   <li>Example: <tt>WAF Classic</tt><pre>"{\"type\": \"WAF\",
--   \"ruleGroups\": [{\"id\":\"12345678-1bcd-9012-efga-0987654321ab\",
--   \"overrideAction\" : {\"type\": \"COUNT\"}}], \"defaultAction\":
--   {\"type\": \"BLOCK\"}}"</pre></li>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>SECURITY_GROUPS_COMMON</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"SECURITY_GROUPS_COMMON\",\"revertManualSecurityGroupChanges\":false,\"exclusiveResourceSecurityGroupManagement\":false,
--   \"applyToAllEC2InstanceENIs\":false,\"securityGroups\":[{\"id\":\"
--   sg-000e55995d61a06bd\"}]}"</pre></li>
--   <li>Example: Shared VPCs. Apply the preceding policy to resources in
--   shared VPCs as well as to those in VPCs that the account
--   owns<pre>"{\"type\":\"SECURITY_GROUPS_COMMON\",\"revertManualSecurityGroupChanges\":false,\"exclusiveResourceSecurityGroupManagement\":false,
--   \"applyToAllEC2InstanceENIs\":false,\"includeSharedVPC\":true,\"securityGroups\":[{\"id\":\"
--   sg-000e55995d61a06bd\"}]}"</pre></li>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>SECURITY_GROUPS_CONTENT_AUDIT</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"SECURITY_GROUPS_CONTENT_AUDIT\",\"securityGroups\":[{\"id\":\"sg-000e55995d61a06bd\"}],\"securityGroupAction\":{\"type\":\"ALLOW\"}}"</pre>The
--   security group action for content audit can be <tt>ALLOW</tt> or
--   <tt>DENY</tt>. For <tt>ALLOW</tt>, all in-scope security group rules
--   must be within the allowed range of the policy's security group rules.
--   For <tt>DENY</tt>, all in-scope security group rules must not contain
--   a value or a range that matches a rule value or range in the policy
--   security group.</li>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>SECURITY_GROUPS_USAGE_AUDIT</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"SECURITY_GROUPS_USAGE_AUDIT\",\"deleteUnusedSecurityGroups\":true,\"coalesceRedundantSecurityGroups\":true}"</pre></li>
--   </ul>
securityServicePolicyData_managedServiceData :: Lens' SecurityServicePolicyData (Maybe Text)

-- | The service that the policy is using to protect the resources. This
--   specifies the type of policy that is created, either an WAF policy, a
--   Shield Advanced policy, or a security group policy. For security group
--   policies, Firewall Manager supports one security group for each common
--   policy and for each content audit policy. This is an adjustable limit
--   that you can increase by contacting Amazon Web Services Support.
securityServicePolicyData_type :: Lens' SecurityServicePolicyData SecurityServiceType

-- | The resource ID of the rule group.
statefulRuleGroup_resourceId :: Lens' StatefulRuleGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of the rule group.
statefulRuleGroup_ruleGroupName :: Lens' StatefulRuleGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The resource ID of the rule group.
statelessRuleGroup_resourceId :: Lens' StatelessRuleGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The priority of the rule group. Network Firewall evaluates the
--   stateless rule groups in a firewall policy starting from the lowest
--   priority setting.
statelessRuleGroup_priority :: Lens' StatelessRuleGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | The name of the rule group.
statelessRuleGroup_ruleGroupName :: Lens' StatelessRuleGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | Part of the key:value pair that defines a tag. You can use a tag key
--   to describe a category of information, such as "customer." Tag keys
--   are case-sensitive.
tag_key :: Lens' Tag Text

-- | Part of the key:value pair that defines a tag. You can use a tag value
--   to describe a specific value within a category, such as "companyA" or
--   "companyB." Tag values are case-sensitive.
tag_value :: Lens' Tag Text

-- | Brief description for the requested resource.
violationDetail_resourceDescription :: Lens' ViolationDetail (Maybe Text)

-- | The <tt>ResourceTag</tt> objects associated with the resource.
violationDetail_resourceTags :: Lens' ViolationDetail (Maybe [Tag])

-- | The ID of the Firewall Manager policy that the violation details were
--   requested for.
violationDetail_policyId :: Lens' ViolationDetail Text

-- | The Amazon Web Services account that the violation details were
--   requested for.
violationDetail_memberAccount :: Lens' ViolationDetail Text

-- | The resource ID that the violation details were requested for.
violationDetail_resourceId :: Lens' ViolationDetail Text

-- | The resource type that the violation details were requested for.
violationDetail_resourceType :: Lens' ViolationDetail Text

-- | List of violations for the requested resource.
violationDetail_resourceViolations :: Lens' ViolationDetail [ResourceViolation]

--   required permissions for API actions</a>.

-- | API version <tt>2018-01-01</tt> of the Amazon Firewall Management
--   Service SDK configuration.
defaultService :: Service

-- | The value of the <tt>Type</tt> parameter is invalid.
_InvalidTypeException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The operation failed because there was nothing to do or the operation
--   wasn't possible. For example, you might have submitted an
--   <tt>AssociateAdminAccount</tt> request for an account ID that was
--   already set as the Firewall Manager administrator. Or you might have
--   tried to access a Region that's disabled by default, and that you need
--   to enable for the Firewall Manager administrator account and for
--   Organizations before you can access it.
_InvalidOperationException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The operation failed because of a system problem, even though the
--   request was valid. Retry your request.
_InternalErrorException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The parameters of the request were invalid.
_InvalidInputException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The operation exceeds a resource limit, for example, the maximum
--   number of <tt>policy</tt> objects that you can create for an Amazon
--   Web Services account. For more information, see <a>Firewall Manager
--   Limits</a> in the <i>WAF Developer Guide</i>.
_LimitExceededException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The specified resource was not found.
_ResourceNotFoundException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeletePolicy</a> smart constructor.
data DeletePolicy
DeletePolicy' :: Maybe Bool -> Text -> DeletePolicy

-- | Create a value of <a>DeletePolicy</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:deleteAllPolicyResources:DeletePolicy'</a>,
--   <a>deletePolicy_deleteAllPolicyResources</a> - If <tt>True</tt>, the
--   request performs cleanup according to the policy type.
--   
--   For WAF and Shield Advanced policies, the cleanup does the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Deletes rule groups created by Firewall Manager</li>
--   <li>Removes web ACLs from in-scope resources</li>
--   <li>Deletes web ACLs that contain no rules or rule groups</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For security group policies, the cleanup does the following for each
--   security group in the policy:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Disassociates the security group from in-scope resources</li>
--   <li>Deletes the security group if it was created through Firewall
--   Manager and if it's no longer associated with any resources through
--   another policy</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   After the cleanup, in-scope resources are no longer protected by web
--   ACLs in this policy. Protection of out-of-scope resources remains
--   unchanged. Scope is determined by tags that you create and accounts
--   that you associate with the policy. When creating the policy, if you
--   specify that only resources in specific accounts or with specific tags
--   are in scope of the policy, those accounts and resources are handled
--   by the policy. All others are out of scope. If you don't specify tags
--   or accounts, all resources are in scope.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyId:DeletePolicy'</a>, <a>deletePolicy_policyId</a> - The
--   ID of the policy that you want to delete. You can retrieve this ID
--   from <tt>PutPolicy</tt> and <tt>ListPolicies</tt>.
newDeletePolicy :: Text -> DeletePolicy

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeletePolicyResponse</a> smart constructor.

--   omitted.

--   specify for <tt>MaxResults</tt>, Firewall Manager returns a
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> value in the response, which you can use to

--   <tt>GetProtectionStatus</tt> requests, specify the value of

--   query for the attacks. This is a <tt>timestamp</tt> type. The request
--   syntax listing indicates a <tt>number</tt> type because the default
--   used by Firewall Manager is Unix time in seconds. However, any valid
--   <tt>timestamp</tt> format is allowed.

--   <a>$sel:endTime:GetProtectionStatus'</a>,
--   <a>getProtectionStatus_endTime</a> - The end of the time period to
--   query for the attacks. This is a <tt>timestamp</tt> type. The request
--   syntax listing indicates a <tt>number</tt> type because the default
--   used by Firewall Manager is Unix time in seconds. However, any valid
--   <tt>timestamp</tt> format is allowed.

--   <a>getProtectionStatus_memberAccountId</a> - The Amazon Web Services
--   account that is in scope of the policy that you want to get the
--   details for.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyId:GetProtectionStatus'</a>,
--   <a>getProtectionStatus_policyId</a> - The ID of the policy for which
--   you want to get the attack information.

-- | Create a value of <a>GetProtectionStatusResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   objects than the number that you specified for <tt>MaxResults</tt> in
--   the request, the response includes a <tt>NextToken</tt> value. To list
--   more objects, submit another <tt>GetProtectionStatus</tt> request, and
--   specify the <tt>NextToken</tt> value from the response in the
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> value in the next request.
--   
--   Amazon Web Services SDKs provide auto-pagination that identify
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> in a response and make subsequent request calls
--   automatically on your behalf. However, this feature is not supported
--   by <tt>GetProtectionStatus</tt>. You must submit subsequent requests
--   with <tt>NextToken</tt> using your own processes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:adminAccountId:GetProtectionStatusResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getProtectionStatusResponse_adminAccountId</a> - The ID of the
--   Firewall Manager administrator account for this policy.
--

--   <a>getProtectionStatusResponse_data</a> - Details about the attack,
--   including the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Attack type</li>
--   <li>Account ID</li>
--   <li>ARN of the resource attacked</li>
--   <li>Start time of the attack</li>
--   <li>End time of the attack (ongoing attacks will not have an end
--   time)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The details are in JSON format.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceType:GetProtectionStatusResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getProtectionStatusResponse_serviceType</a> - The service type that
--   is protected by the policy. Currently, this is always
--   <tt>SHIELD_ADVANCED</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:GetProtectionStatusResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getProtectionStatusResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.

--   the next batch of objects.

--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:listId:DeleteProtocolsList'</a>,
--   <a>deleteProtocolsList_listId</a> - The ID of the protocols list that
--   you want to delete. You can retrieve this ID from
--   <tt>PutProtocolsList</tt>, <tt>ListProtocolsLists</tt>, and
--   <tt>GetProtocolsLost</tt>.
newDeleteProtocolsList :: Text -> DeleteProtocolsList

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:nextToken:ListMemberAccounts'</a>,
--   <a>listMemberAccounts_nextToken</a> - If you specify a value for
--   <tt>MaxResults</tt> and you have more account IDs than the number that
--   you specify for <tt>MaxResults</tt>, Firewall Manager returns a
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> value in the response that allows you to list
--   another group of IDs. For the second and subsequent
--   <tt>ListMemberAccountsRequest</tt> requests, specify the value of
--   <tt>NextToken</tt> from the previous response to get information about
--   another batch of member account IDs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxResults:ListMemberAccounts'</a>,
--   <a>listMemberAccounts_maxResults</a> - Specifies the number of member
--   account IDs that you want Firewall Manager to return for this request.
--   If you have more IDs than the number that you specify for
--   <tt>MaxResults</tt>, the response includes a <tt>NextToken</tt> value
--   that you can use to get another batch of member account IDs.
newListMemberAccounts :: ListMemberAccounts

--   in the request, the response includes a <tt>NextToken</tt> value. To
--   list more IDs, submit another <tt>ListMemberAccounts</tt> request, and

-- | An individual Firewall Manager application.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newApp</a> smart constructor.
data App

--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--

--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:App'</a>, <a>app_protocol</a> - The IP protocol name
--   or number. The name can be one of <tt>tcp</tt>, <tt>udp</tt>, or
--   <tt>icmp</tt>. For information on possible numbers, see <a>Protocol
--   Numbers</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:port:App'</a>, <a>app_port</a> - The application's port
--   number, for example <tt>80</tt>.
newApp :: Text -> Text -> Natural -> App

--   omitted.

--   Manager applications list was last updated.

--   of the Firewall Manager applications list.

--   The time that the Firewall Manager applications list was created.

--   numbers to their corresponding <tt>App</tt> object arrays.

--   <a>appsListData_listUpdateToken</a> - A unique identifier for each
--   update to the list. When you update the list, the update token must
--   match the token of the current version of the application list. You
--   can retrieve the update token by getting the list.
--   
--   <a>$sel:listName:AppsListData'</a>, <a>appsListData_listName</a> - The
--   name of the Firewall Manager applications list.
--   
--   <a>$sel:appsList:AppsListData'</a>, <a>appsListData_appsList</a> - An
--   array of applications in the Firewall Manager applications list.
newAppsListData :: Text -> AppsListData

--   <tt>ViolationTarget</tt>.

--   partially match the <tt>ViolationTarget</tt> rule.

--   <a>awsVPCSecurityGroupViolation_violationTargetDescription</a> - A
--   description of the security group that violates the policy.
newAwsVPCSecurityGroupViolation :: AwsVPCSecurityGroupViolation

-- | Details of the resource that is not protected by the policy.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newComplianceViolator</a> smart constructor.
data ComplianceViolator

-- | Create a value of <a>ComplianceViolator</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceId:ComplianceViolator'</a>,
--   <a>complianceViolator_resourceId</a> - The resource ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:ComplianceViolator'</a>,
--   <a>complianceViolator_resourceType</a> - The resource type. This is in
--   the format shown in the <a>Amazon Web Services Resource Types
--   Reference</a>. For example:
--   <tt>AWS::ElasticLoadBalancingV2::LoadBalancer</tt>,
--   <tt>AWS::CloudFront::Distribution</tt>, or
--   <tt>AWS::NetworkFirewall::FirewallPolicy</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:violationReason:ComplianceViolator'</a>,
--   <a>complianceViolator_violationReason</a> - The reason that the
--   resource is not protected by the policy.
newComplianceViolator :: ComplianceViolator

-- | A DNS Firewall rule group that Firewall Manager tried to associate
--   with a VPC is already associated with the VPC and can't be associated
--   again.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDnsDuplicateRuleGroupViolation</a> smart
--   constructor.
data DnsDuplicateRuleGroupViolation

--   <a>dnsDuplicateRuleGroupViolation_violationTargetDescription</a> - A
--   description of the violation that specifies the rule group and VPC.
newDnsDuplicateRuleGroupViolation :: DnsDuplicateRuleGroupViolation

-- | The VPC that Firewall Manager was applying a DNS Fireall policy to
--   reached the limit for associated DNS Firewall rule groups. Firewall
--   Manager tried to associate another rule group with the VPC and failed
--   due to the limit.

--   constructor.

-- | A rule group that Firewall Manager tried to associate with a VPC has
--   the same priority as a rule group that's already associated.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation</a> smart
--   constructor.
data DnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation

-- | Create a value of <a>DnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation</a> with
--   all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   priority setting of the two conflicting rule groups.
--

--   group that's already associated with it.
--

--   <a>dnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation_unavailablePriorities</a> -
--   The priorities of rule groups that are already associated with the
--   VPC. To retry your operation, choose priority settings that aren't in
--   this list for the rule groups in your new DNS Firewall policy.
--

--   <a>$sel:conflictingPolicyId:DnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation'</a>,
--   <a>dnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation_conflictingPolicyId</a> - The
--   ID of the Firewall Manager DNS Firewall policy that was already
--   applied to the VPC. This policy contains the rule group that's already
--   associated with the VPC.
newDnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation :: DnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation

-- | Describes the compliance status for the account. An account is
--   considered noncompliant if it includes resources that are not
--   protected by the specified policy or that don't comply with the
--   policy.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEvaluationResult</a> smart constructor.
data EvaluationResult
EvaluationResult' :: Maybe PolicyComplianceStatusType -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Natural -> EvaluationResult

-- | Create a value of <a>EvaluationResult</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:complianceStatus:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_complianceStatus</a> - Describes an Amazon Web
--   Services account's compliance with the Firewall Manager policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evaluationLimitExceeded:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_evaluationLimitExceeded</a> - Indicates that over
--   100 resources are noncompliant with the Firewall Manager policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:violatorCount:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_violatorCount</a> - The number of resources that
--   are noncompliant with the specified policy. For WAF and Shield
--   Advanced policies, a resource is considered noncompliant if it is not
--   associated with the policy. For security group policies, a resource is
--   considered noncompliant if it doesn't comply with the rules of the
--   policy and remediation is disabled or not possible.
newEvaluationResult :: EvaluationResult

--   
--   <a>$sel:subnetId:NetworkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation'</a>,

--   The subnet ID.

--   <a>networkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation_internetGatewayId</a>
--   - The internet gateway ID.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:violatingRoutes:NetworkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation'</a>,
--   <a>networkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation_violatingRoutes</a>
--   - The route or routes that are in violation.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:expectedFirewallEndpoint:NetworkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation'</a>,
--   <a>networkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation_expectedFirewallEndpoint</a>
--   - The expected endpoint for the current firewall.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:firewallSubnetId:NetworkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation'</a>,
--   <a>networkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation_firewallSubnetId</a>
--   - The firewall subnet ID.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:vpcId:NetworkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation'</a>,
--   <a>networkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation_vpcId</a> -
--   Information about the VPC ID.
newNetworkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation :: NetworkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation

-- | Violation detail for the improperly configured subnet route. It's
--   possible there is a missing route table route, or a configuration that
--   causes traffic to cross an Availability Zone boundary.

--   <a>newNetworkFirewallInvalidRouteConfigurationViolation</a> smart
--   constructor.
