-- | The reference rule that partially matches the <tt>ViolationTarget</tt>
--   rule and violation reason.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPartialMatch</a> smart constructor.
data PartialMatch
PartialMatch' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> PartialMatch

-- | Create a value of <a>PartialMatch</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:targetViolationReasons:PartialMatch'</a>,
--   <a>partialMatch_targetViolationReasons</a> - The violation reason.
--   
--   <a>$sel:reference:PartialMatch'</a>, <a>partialMatch_reference</a> -
--   The reference rule from the primary security group of the Firewall
--   Manager policy.
newPartialMatch :: PartialMatch

-- | An Firewall Manager policy.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPolicy</a> smart constructor.
data Policy
Policy' :: Maybe [ResourceTag] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (HashMap CustomerPolicyScopeIdType [Text]) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (HashMap CustomerPolicyScopeIdType [Text]) -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> SecurityServicePolicyData -> Text -> Bool -> Bool -> Policy

-- | Create a value of <a>Policy</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceTags:Policy'</a>, <a>policy_resourceTags</a> - An
--   array of <tt>ResourceTag</tt> objects.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceTypeList:Policy'</a>, <a>policy_resourceTypeList</a> -
--   An array of <tt>ResourceType</tt> objects. Use this only to specify
--   multiple resource types. To specify a single resource type, use
--   <tt>ResourceType</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyUpdateToken:Policy'</a>, <a>policy_policyUpdateToken</a>
--   - A unique identifier for each update to the policy. When issuing a
--   <tt>PutPolicy</tt> request, the <tt>PolicyUpdateToken</tt> in the
--   request must match the <tt>PolicyUpdateToken</tt> of the current
--   policy version. To get the <tt>PolicyUpdateToken</tt> of the current
--   policy version, use a <tt>GetPolicy</tt> request.
--   
--   <a>$sel:includeMap:Policy'</a>, <a>policy_includeMap</a> - Specifies
--   the Amazon Web Services account IDs and Organizations organizational
--   units (OUs) to include in the policy. Specifying an OU is the
--   equivalent of specifying all accounts in the OU and in any of its
--   child OUs, including any child OUs and accounts that are added at a
--   later time.
--   
--   You can specify inclusions or exclusions, but not both. If you specify
--   an <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, Firewall Manager applies the policy to all
--   accounts specified by the <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, and does not evaluate
--   any <tt>ExcludeMap</tt> specifications. If you do not specify an
--   <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, then Firewall Manager applies the policy to all
--   accounts except for those specified by the <tt>ExcludeMap</tt>.
--   
--   You can specify account IDs, OUs, or a combination:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specify account IDs by setting the key to <tt>ACCOUNT</tt>. For
--   example, the following is a valid map: <tt>{ACCOUNT : [accountID1,
--   accountID2]}</tt>.</li>
--   <li>Specify OUs by setting the key to <tt>ORG_UNIT</tt>. For example,
--   the following is a valid map: <tt>{ORG_UNIT : [ouid111,
--   ouid112]}</tt>.</li>
--   <li>Specify accounts and OUs together in a single map, separated with
--   a comma. For example, the following is a valid map: <tt>{ACCOUNT :
--   [accountID1, accountID2], ORG_UNIT : [ouid111,
--   ouid112]}</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyId:Policy'</a>, <a>policy_policyId</a> - The ID of the
--   Firewall Manager policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:excludeMap:Policy'</a>, <a>policy_excludeMap</a> - Specifies
--   the Amazon Web Services account IDs and Organizations organizational
--   units (OUs) to exclude from the policy. Specifying an OU is the
--   equivalent of specifying all accounts in the OU and in any of its
--   child OUs, including any child OUs and accounts that are added at a
--   later time.
--   
--   You can specify inclusions or exclusions, but not both. If you specify
--   an <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, Firewall Manager applies the policy to all
--   accounts specified by the <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, and does not evaluate
--   any <tt>ExcludeMap</tt> specifications. If you do not specify an
--   <tt>IncludeMap</tt>, then Firewall Manager applies the policy to all
--   accounts except for those specified by the <tt>ExcludeMap</tt>.
--   
--   You can specify account IDs, OUs, or a combination:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specify account IDs by setting the key to <tt>ACCOUNT</tt>. For
--   example, the following is a valid map: <tt>{ACCOUNT : [accountID1,
--   accountID2]}</tt>.</li>
--   <li>Specify OUs by setting the key to <tt>ORG_UNIT</tt>. For example,
--   the following is a valid map: <tt>{ORG_UNIT : [ouid111,
--   ouid112]}</tt>.</li>
--   <li>Specify accounts and OUs together in a single map, separated with
--   a comma. For example, the following is a valid map: <tt>{ACCOUNT :
--   [accountID1, accountID2], ORG_UNIT : [ouid111,
--   ouid112]}</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:deleteUnusedFMManagedResources:Policy'</a>,
--   <a>policy_deleteUnusedFMManagedResources</a> - Indicates whether
--   Firewall Manager should delete Firewall Manager managed resources,
--   such as web ACLs and security groups, when they are not in use by the
--   Firewall Manager policy. By default, Firewall Manager doesn't delete
--   unused Firewall Manager managed resources. This option is not
--   available for Shield Advanced or WAF Classic policies.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyName:Policy'</a>, <a>policy_policyName</a> - The name of
--   the Firewall Manager policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:securityServicePolicyData:Policy'</a>,
--   <a>policy_securityServicePolicyData</a> - Details about the security
--   service that is being used to protect the resources.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:Policy'</a>, <a>policy_resourceType</a> - The
--   type of resource protected by or in scope of the policy. This is in
--   the format shown in the <a>Amazon Web Services Resource Types
--   Reference</a>. To apply this policy to multiple resource types,
--   specify a resource type of <tt>ResourceTypeList</tt> and then specify
--   the resource types in a <tt>ResourceTypeList</tt>.
--   
--   For WAF and Shield Advanced, example resource types include
--   <tt>AWS::ElasticLoadBalancingV2::LoadBalancer</tt> and
--   <tt>AWS::CloudFront::Distribution</tt>. For a security group common
--   policy, valid values are <tt>AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface</tt> and
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>. For a security group content audit
--   policy, valid values are <tt>AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup</tt>,
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface</tt>, and <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>.
--   For a security group usage audit policy, the value is
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup</tt>. For an Network Firewall policy or
--   DNS Firewall policy, the value is <tt>AWS::EC2::VPC</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:excludeResourceTags:Policy'</a>,
--   <a>policy_excludeResourceTags</a> - If set to <tt>True</tt>, resources
--   with the tags that are specified in the <tt>ResourceTag</tt> array are
--   not in scope of the policy. If set to <tt>False</tt>, and the
--   <tt>ResourceTag</tt> array is not null, only resources with the
--   specified tags are in scope of the policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:remediationEnabled:Policy'</a>,
--   <a>policy_remediationEnabled</a> - Indicates if the policy should be
--   automatically applied to new resources.
newPolicy :: Text -> SecurityServicePolicyData -> Text -> Bool -> Bool -> Policy

-- | Describes the noncompliant resources in a member account for a
--   specific Firewall Manager policy. A maximum of 100 entries are
--   displayed. If more than 100 resources are noncompliant,
--   <tt>EvaluationLimitExceeded</tt> is set to <tt>True</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPolicyComplianceDetail</a> smart constructor.
data PolicyComplianceDetail
PolicyComplianceDetail' :: Maybe [ComplianceViolator] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe (HashMap DependentServiceName Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> PolicyComplianceDetail

-- | Create a value of <a>PolicyComplianceDetail</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:violators:PolicyComplianceDetail'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceDetail_violators</a> - An array of resources that
--   aren't protected by the WAF or Shield Advanced policy or that aren't
--   in compliance with the security group policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyOwner:PolicyComplianceDetail'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceDetail_policyOwner</a> - The Amazon Web Services
--   account that created the Firewall Manager policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:memberAccount:PolicyComplianceDetail'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceDetail_memberAccount</a> - The Amazon Web Services
--   account ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evaluationLimitExceeded:PolicyComplianceDetail'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceDetail_evaluationLimitExceeded</a> - Indicates if
--   over 100 resources are noncompliant with the Firewall Manager policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:issueInfoMap:PolicyComplianceDetail'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceDetail_issueInfoMap</a> - Details about problems
--   with dependent services, such as WAF or Config, and the error message
--   received that indicates the problem with the service.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyId:PolicyComplianceDetail'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceDetail_policyId</a> - The ID of the Firewall
--   Manager policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:expiredAt:PolicyComplianceDetail'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceDetail_expiredAt</a> - A timestamp that indicates
--   when the returned information should be considered out of date.
newPolicyComplianceDetail :: PolicyComplianceDetail

-- | Indicates whether the account is compliant with the specified policy.
--   An account is considered noncompliant if it includes resources that
--   are not protected by the policy, for WAF and Shield Advanced policies,
--   or that are noncompliant with the policy, for security group policies.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPolicyComplianceStatus</a> smart constructor.
data PolicyComplianceStatus
PolicyComplianceStatus' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe [EvaluationResult] -> Maybe (HashMap DependentServiceName Text) -> Maybe Text -> PolicyComplianceStatus

-- | Create a value of <a>PolicyComplianceStatus</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyName:PolicyComplianceStatus'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceStatus_policyName</a> - The name of the Firewall
--   Manager policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyOwner:PolicyComplianceStatus'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceStatus_policyOwner</a> - The Amazon Web Services
--   account that created the Firewall Manager policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:memberAccount:PolicyComplianceStatus'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceStatus_memberAccount</a> - The member account ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastUpdated:PolicyComplianceStatus'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceStatus_lastUpdated</a> - Timestamp of the last
--   update to the <tt>EvaluationResult</tt> objects.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evaluationResults:PolicyComplianceStatus'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceStatus_evaluationResults</a> - An array of
--   <tt>EvaluationResult</tt> objects.
--   
--   <a>$sel:issueInfoMap:PolicyComplianceStatus'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceStatus_issueInfoMap</a> - Details about problems
--   with dependent services, such as WAF or Config, and the error message
--   received that indicates the problem with the service.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyId:PolicyComplianceStatus'</a>,
--   <a>policyComplianceStatus_policyId</a> - The ID of the Firewall
--   Manager policy.
newPolicyComplianceStatus :: PolicyComplianceStatus

-- | Details of the Firewall Manager policy.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPolicySummary</a> smart constructor.
data PolicySummary
PolicySummary' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe SecurityServiceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> PolicySummary

-- | Create a value of <a>PolicySummary</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyName:PolicySummary'</a>, <a>policySummary_policyName</a>
--   - The name of the specified policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:securityServiceType:PolicySummary'</a>,
--   <a>policySummary_securityServiceType</a> - The service that the policy
--   is using to protect the resources. This specifies the type of policy
--   that is created, either an WAF policy, a Shield Advanced policy, or a
--   security group policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:PolicySummary'</a>,
--   <a>policySummary_resourceType</a> - The type of resource protected by
--   or in scope of the policy. This is in the format shown in the
--   <a>Amazon Web Services Resource Types Reference</a>. For WAF and
--   Shield Advanced, examples include
--   <tt>AWS::ElasticLoadBalancingV2::LoadBalancer</tt> and
--   <tt>AWS::CloudFront::Distribution</tt>. For a security group common
--   policy, valid values are <tt>AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface</tt> and
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>. For a security group content audit
--   policy, valid values are <tt>AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup</tt>,
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface</tt>, and <tt>AWS::EC2::Instance</tt>.
--   For a security group usage audit policy, the value is
--   <tt>AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup</tt>. For an Network Firewall policy or
--   DNS Firewall policy, the value is <tt>AWS::EC2::VPC</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:remediationEnabled:PolicySummary'</a>,
--   <a>policySummary_remediationEnabled</a> - Indicates if the policy
--   should be automatically applied to new resources.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyArn:PolicySummary'</a>, <a>policySummary_policyArn</a> -
--   The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the specified policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyId:PolicySummary'</a>, <a>policySummary_policyId</a> -
--   The ID of the specified policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:deleteUnusedFMManagedResources:PolicySummary'</a>,
--   <a>policySummary_deleteUnusedFMManagedResources</a> - Indicates
--   whether Firewall Manager should delete Firewall Manager managed
--   resources, such as web ACLs and security groups, when they are not in
--   use by the Firewall Manager policy. By default, Firewall Manager
--   doesn't delete unused Firewall Manager managed resources. This option
--   is not available for Shield Advanced or WAF Classic policies.
newPolicySummary :: PolicySummary

-- | A list of remediation actions.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPossibleRemediationAction</a> smart constructor.
data PossibleRemediationAction

--   fields omitted.

--   fields.

--   list of remediation actions.
--   
--   <a>$sel:orderedRemediationActions:PossibleRemediationAction'</a>,
--   <a>possibleRemediationAction_orderedRemediationActions</a> - The
--   ordered list of remediation actions.
newPossibleRemediationAction :: PossibleRemediationAction

-- | A list of possible remediation action lists. Each individual possible
--   remediation action is a list of individual remediation actions.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPossibleRemediationActions</a> smart constructor.
data PossibleRemediationActions
PossibleRemediationActions' :: Maybe [PossibleRemediationAction] -> Maybe Text -> PossibleRemediationActions

--   fields omitted.

--   possible remediation actions list.
newPossibleRemediationActions :: PossibleRemediationActions

--   must match the token of the current version of the application list.

--   protocols list.

--   Firewall Manager protocols list.
newProtocolsListData :: Text -> ProtocolsListData

-- | Information about an individual action you can take to remediate a
--   violation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRemediationAction</a> smart constructor.
data RemediationAction
RemediationAction' :: Maybe EC2CreateRouteAction -> Maybe EC2ReplaceRouteAction -> Maybe EC2AssociateRouteTableAction -> Maybe EC2CreateRouteTableAction -> Maybe Text -> Maybe EC2CopyRouteTableAction -> Maybe EC2ReplaceRouteTableAssociationAction -> Maybe EC2DeleteRouteAction -> RemediationAction

-- | Create a value of <a>RemediationAction</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:eC2CreateRouteAction:RemediationAction'</a>,

--   CreateRoute action in the Amazon EC2 API.
--   
--   <a>$sel:eC2ReplaceRouteAction:RemediationAction'</a>,
--   <a>remediationAction_eC2ReplaceRouteAction</a> - Information about the
--   ReplaceRoute action in the Amazon EC2 API.
--

--   <a>remediationAction_eC2AssociateRouteTableAction</a> - Information
--   about the AssociateRouteTable action in the Amazon EC2 API.

--   <a>$sel:eC2CreateRouteTableAction:RemediationAction'</a>,

--   <a>remediationAction_description</a> - A description of a remediation
--   action.

--   Amazon EC2 API.

--   <a>remediationAction_eC2DeleteRouteAction</a> - Information about the
--   DeleteRoute action in the Amazon EC2 API.
newRemediationAction :: RemediationAction

-- | An ordered list of actions you can take to remediate a violation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRemediationActionWithOrder</a> smart constructor.
data RemediationActionWithOrder

--   fields omitted.

--   about an action you can take to remediate a violation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:order:RemediationActionWithOrder'</a>,
--   <a>remediationActionWithOrder_order</a> - The order of the remediation
--   actions in the list.
newRemediationActionWithOrder :: RemediationActionWithOrder

-- | The resource tags that Firewall Manager uses to determine if a
--   particular resource should be included or excluded from the Firewall
--   Manager policy. Tags enable you to categorize your Amazon Web Services
--   resources in different ways, for example, by purpose, owner, or
--   environment. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value.
--   Firewall Manager combines the tags with "AND" so that, if you add more
--   than one tag to a policy scope, a resource must have all the specified
--   tags to be included or excluded. For more information, see <a>Working
--   with Tag Editor</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newResourceTag</a> smart constructor.
data ResourceTag
ResourceTag' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> ResourceTag

-- | Create a value of <a>ResourceTag</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:ResourceTag'</a>, <a>resourceTag_value</a> - The
--   resource tag value.
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:ResourceTag'</a>, <a>resourceTag_key</a> - The resource
--   tag key.
newResourceTag :: Text -> ResourceTag

-- | Violation detail based on resource type.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newResourceViolation</a> smart constructor.
data ResourceViolation
ResourceViolation' :: Maybe NetworkFirewallBlackHoleRouteDetectedViolation -> Maybe PossibleRemediationActions -> Maybe DnsRuleGroupLimitExceededViolation -> Maybe NetworkFirewallInvalidRouteConfigurationViolation -> Maybe NetworkFirewallMissingSubnetViolation -> Maybe DnsDuplicateRuleGroupViolation -> Maybe AwsEc2NetworkInterfaceViolation -> Maybe NetworkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation -> Maybe NetworkFirewallMissingExpectedRTViolation -> Maybe NetworkFirewallMissingExpectedRoutesViolation -> Maybe AwsEc2InstanceViolation -> Maybe NetworkFirewallUnexpectedGatewayRoutesViolation -> Maybe NetworkFirewallMissingFirewallViolation -> Maybe NetworkFirewallUnexpectedFirewallRoutesViolation -> Maybe AwsVPCSecurityGroupViolation -> Maybe NetworkFirewallPolicyModifiedViolation -> Maybe DnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation -> ResourceViolation

-- | Create a value of <a>ResourceViolation</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:networkFirewallBlackHoleRouteDetectedViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_networkFirewallBlackHoleRouteDetectedViolation</a>
--   - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:possibleRemediationActions:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_possibleRemediationActions</a> - A list of
--   possible remediation action lists. Each individual possible
--   remediation action is a list of individual remediation actions.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dnsRuleGroupLimitExceededViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_dnsRuleGroupLimitExceededViolation</a> -
--   Violation detail for a DNS Firewall policy that indicates that the VPC
--   reached the limit for associated DNS Firewall rule groups. Firewall
--   Manager tried to associate another rule group with the VPC and failed.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:networkFirewallInvalidRouteConfigurationViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_networkFirewallInvalidRouteConfigurationViolation</a>
--   - The route configuration is invalid.
--   
--   <a>$sel:networkFirewallMissingSubnetViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_networkFirewallMissingSubnetViolation</a> -
--   Violation detail for an Network Firewall policy that indicates that an
--   Availability Zone is missing the expected Firewall Manager managed
--   subnet.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dnsDuplicateRuleGroupViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_dnsDuplicateRuleGroupViolation</a> - Violation
--   detail for a DNS Firewall policy that indicates that a rule group that
--   Firewall Manager tried to associate with a VPC is already associated
--   with the VPC and can't be associated again.
--   
--   <a>$sel:awsEc2NetworkInterfaceViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_awsEc2NetworkInterfaceViolation</a> - Violation
--   detail for a network interface.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:networkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_networkFirewallInternetTrafficNotInspectedViolation</a>
--   - Violation detail for the subnet for which internet traffic hasn't
--   been inspected.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:networkFirewallMissingExpectedRTViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_networkFirewallMissingExpectedRTViolation</a> -
--   Violation detail for an Network Firewall policy that indicates that a
--   subnet is not associated with the expected Firewall Manager managed
--   route table.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:networkFirewallMissingExpectedRoutesViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_networkFirewallMissingExpectedRoutesViolation</a>
--   - Expected routes are missing from Network Firewall.
--   
--   <a>$sel:awsEc2InstanceViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_awsEc2InstanceViolation</a> - Violation detail
--   for an EC2 instance.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:networkFirewallUnexpectedGatewayRoutesViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_networkFirewallUnexpectedGatewayRoutesViolation</a>
--   - There's an unexpected gateway route.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:networkFirewallMissingFirewallViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_networkFirewallMissingFirewallViolation</a> -
--   Violation detail for an Network Firewall policy that indicates that a
--   subnet has no Firewall Manager managed firewall in its VPC.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:networkFirewallUnexpectedFirewallRoutesViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_networkFirewallUnexpectedFirewallRoutesViolation</a>
--   - There's an unexpected firewall route.
--   
--   <a>$sel:awsVPCSecurityGroupViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_awsVPCSecurityGroupViolation</a> - Violation
--   detail for security groups.
--   
--   <a>$sel:networkFirewallPolicyModifiedViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_networkFirewallPolicyModifiedViolation</a> -
--   Violation detail for an Network Firewall policy that indicates that a
--   firewall policy in an individual account has been modified in a way
--   that makes it noncompliant. For example, the individual account owner
--   might have deleted a rule group, changed the priority of a stateless
--   rule group, or changed a policy default action.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation:ResourceViolation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceViolation_dnsRuleGroupPriorityConflictViolation</a> -
--   Violation detail for a DNS Firewall policy that indicates that a rule
--   group that Firewall Manager tried to associate with a VPC has the same
--   priority as a rule group that's already associated.
newResourceViolation :: ResourceViolation

-- | Describes a route in a route table.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRoute</a> smart constructor.
data Route
Route' :: Maybe DestinationType -> Maybe TargetType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Route

-- | Create a value of <a>Route</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationType:Route'</a>, <a>route_destinationType</a> - The
--   type of destination for the route.
--   
--   <a>$sel:targetType:Route'</a>, <a>route_targetType</a> - The type of
--   target for the route.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destination:Route'</a>, <a>route_destination</a> - The
--   destination of the route.
--   
--   <a>$sel:target:Route'</a>, <a>route_target</a> - The route's target.
newRoute :: Route

-- | Remediation option for the rule specified in the
--   <tt>ViolationTarget</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSecurityGroupRemediationAction</a> smart
--   constructor.
data SecurityGroupRemediationAction
SecurityGroupRemediationAction' :: Maybe RemediationActionType -> Maybe SecurityGroupRuleDescription -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> SecurityGroupRemediationAction

-- | Create a value of <a>SecurityGroupRemediationAction</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:remediationActionType:SecurityGroupRemediationAction'</a>,
--   <a>securityGroupRemediationAction_remediationActionType</a> - The
--   remediation action that will be performed.
--   
--   <a>$sel:remediationResult:SecurityGroupRemediationAction'</a>,
--   <a>securityGroupRemediationAction_remediationResult</a> - The final
--   state of the rule specified in the <tt>ViolationTarget</tt> after it
--   is remediated.
--   
--   <a>$sel:isDefaultAction:SecurityGroupRemediationAction'</a>,
--   <a>securityGroupRemediationAction_isDefaultAction</a> - Indicates if
--   the current action is the default action.
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:SecurityGroupRemediationAction'</a>,
--   <a>securityGroupRemediationAction_description</a> - Brief description
--   of the action that will be performed.
newSecurityGroupRemediationAction :: SecurityGroupRemediationAction

-- | Describes a set of permissions for a security group rule.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSecurityGroupRuleDescription</a> smart constructor.
data SecurityGroupRuleDescription
SecurityGroupRuleDescription' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> SecurityGroupRuleDescription

-- | Create a value of <a>SecurityGroupRuleDescription</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:SecurityGroupRuleDescription'</a>,
--   <a>securityGroupRuleDescription_fromPort</a> - The start of the port
--   range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP/ICMPv6 type number. A
--   value of <tt>-1</tt> indicates all ICMP/ICMPv6 types.
--   
--   <a>$sel:iPV4Range:SecurityGroupRuleDescription'</a>,
--   <a>securityGroupRuleDescription_iPV4Range</a> - The IPv4 ranges for
--   the security group rule.
--   
--   <a>$sel:prefixListId:SecurityGroupRuleDescription'</a>,
--   <a>securityGroupRuleDescription_prefixListId</a> - The ID of the
--   prefix list for the security group rule.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:SecurityGroupRuleDescription'</a>,
--   <a>securityGroupRuleDescription_protocol</a> - The IP protocol name
--   (<tt>tcp</tt>, <tt>udp</tt>, <tt>icmp</tt>, <tt>icmpv6</tt>) or
--   number.
--   
--   <a>$sel:iPV6Range:SecurityGroupRuleDescription'</a>,
--   <a>securityGroupRuleDescription_iPV6Range</a> - The IPv6 ranges for
--   the security group rule.
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:SecurityGroupRuleDescription'</a>,
--   <a>securityGroupRuleDescription_toPort</a> - The end of the port range
--   for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP/ICMPv6 code. A value of
--   <tt>-1</tt> indicates all ICMP/ICMPv6 codes.
newSecurityGroupRuleDescription :: SecurityGroupRuleDescription

-- | Details about the security service that is being used to protect the
--   resources.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSecurityServicePolicyData</a> smart constructor.
data SecurityServicePolicyData
SecurityServicePolicyData' :: Maybe Text -> SecurityServiceType -> SecurityServicePolicyData

-- | Create a value of <a>SecurityServicePolicyData</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:managedServiceData:SecurityServicePolicyData'</a>,
--   <a>securityServicePolicyData_managedServiceData</a> - Details about
--   the service that are specific to the service type, in JSON format. For
--   service type <tt>SHIELD_ADVANCED</tt>, this is an empty string.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>DNS_FIREWALL</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"DNS_FIREWALL\",\"preProcessRuleGroups\":[{\"ruleGroupId\":\"rslvr-frg-1\",\"priority\":10}],\"postProcessRuleGroups\":[{\"ruleGroupId\":\"rslvr-frg-2\",\"priority\":9911}]}"</pre>Valid
--   values for <tt>preProcessRuleGroups</tt> are between 1 and 99. Valid
--   values for <tt>postProcessRuleGroups</tt> are between 9901 and
--   10000.</li>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>NETWORK_FIREWALL</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"NETWORK_FIREWALL\",\"networkFirewallStatelessRuleGroupReferences\":[{\"resourceARN\":\"arn:aws:network-firewall:us-west-1:1234567891011:stateless-rulegroup/rulegroup2\",\"priority\":10}],\"networkFirewallStatelessDefaultActions\":[\"aws:pass\",\"custom1\"],\"networkFirewallStatelessFragmentDefaultActions\":[\"custom2\",\"aws:pass\"],\"networkFirewallStatelessCustomActions\":[{\"actionName\":\"custom1\",\"actionDefinition\":{\"publishMetricAction\":{\"dimensions\":[{\"value\":\"dimension1\"}]}}},{\"actionName\":\"custom2\",\"actionDefinition\":{\"publishMetricAction\":{\"dimensions\":[{\"value\":\"dimension2\"}]}}}],\"networkFirewallStatefulRuleGroupReferences\":[{\"resourceARN\":\"arn:aws:network-firewall:us-west-1:1234567891011:stateful-rulegroup/rulegroup1\"}],\"networkFirewallOrchestrationConfig\":{\"singleFirewallEndpointPerVPC\":true,\"allowedIPV4CidrList\":[\"10.24.34.0/28\"]}
--   }"</pre></li>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>WAFV2</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"WAFV2\",\"preProcessRuleGroups\":[{\"ruleGroupArn\":null,\"overrideAction\":{\"type\":\"NONE\"},\"managedRuleGroupIdentifier\":{\"version\":null,\"vendorName\":\"AWS\",\"managedRuleGroupName\":\"AWSManagedRulesAmazonIpReputationList\"},\"ruleGroupType\":\"ManagedRuleGroup\",\"excludeRules\":[{\"name\":\"NoUserAgent_HEADER\"}]}],\"postProcessRuleGroups\":[],\"defaultAction\":{\"type\":\"ALLOW\"},\"overrideCustomerWebACLAssociation\":false,\"loggingConfiguration\":{\"logDestinationConfigs\":[\"arn:aws:firehose:us-west-2:12345678912:deliverystream/aws-waf-logs-fms-admin-destination\"],\"redactedFields\":[{\"redactedFieldType\":\"SingleHeader\",\"redactedFieldValue\":\"Cookies\"},{\"redactedFieldType\":\"Method\"}]}}"</pre>In
--   the <tt>loggingConfiguration</tt>, you can specify one
--   <tt>logDestinationConfigs</tt>, you can optionally provide up to 20
--   <tt>redactedFields</tt>, and the <tt>RedactedFieldType</tt> must be
--   one of <tt>URI</tt>, <tt>QUERY_STRING</tt>, <tt>HEADER</tt>, or
--   <tt>METHOD</tt>.</li>
--   <li>Example: <tt>WAF Classic</tt><pre>"{\"type\": \"WAF\",
--   \"ruleGroups\": [{\"id\":\"12345678-1bcd-9012-efga-0987654321ab\",
--   \"overrideAction\" : {\"type\": \"COUNT\"}}], \"defaultAction\":
--   {\"type\": \"BLOCK\"}}"</pre></li>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>SECURITY_GROUPS_COMMON</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"SECURITY_GROUPS_COMMON\",\"revertManualSecurityGroupChanges\":false,\"exclusiveResourceSecurityGroupManagement\":false,
--   \"applyToAllEC2InstanceENIs\":false,\"securityGroups\":[{\"id\":\"
--   sg-000e55995d61a06bd\"}]}"</pre></li>
--   <li>Example: Shared VPCs. Apply the preceding policy to resources in
--   shared VPCs as well as to those in VPCs that the account
--   owns<pre>"{\"type\":\"SECURITY_GROUPS_COMMON\",\"revertManualSecurityGroupChanges\":false,\"exclusiveResourceSecurityGroupManagement\":false,
--   \"applyToAllEC2InstanceENIs\":false,\"includeSharedVPC\":true,\"securityGroups\":[{\"id\":\"
--   sg-000e55995d61a06bd\"}]}"</pre></li>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>SECURITY_GROUPS_CONTENT_AUDIT</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"SECURITY_GROUPS_CONTENT_AUDIT\",\"securityGroups\":[{\"id\":\"sg-000e55995d61a06bd\"}],\"securityGroupAction\":{\"type\":\"ALLOW\"}}"</pre>The
--   security group action for content audit can be <tt>ALLOW</tt> or
--   <tt>DENY</tt>. For <tt>ALLOW</tt>, all in-scope security group rules
--   must be within the allowed range of the policy's security group rules.
--   For <tt>DENY</tt>, all in-scope security group rules must not contain
--   a value or a range that matches a rule value or range in the policy
--   security group.</li>
--   <li>Example:
--   <tt>SECURITY_GROUPS_USAGE_AUDIT</tt><pre>"{\"type\":\"SECURITY_GROUPS_USAGE_AUDIT\",\"deleteUnusedSecurityGroups\":true,\"coalesceRedundantSecurityGroups\":true}"</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':SecurityServicePolicyData'</a>,
--   <a>securityServicePolicyData_type</a> - The service that the policy is
--   using to protect the resources. This specifies the type of policy that
--   is created, either an WAF policy, a Shield Advanced policy, or a
--   security group policy. For security group policies, Firewall Manager
--   supports one security group for each common policy and for each
--   content audit policy. This is an adjustable limit that you can
--   increase by contacting Amazon Web Services Support.
newSecurityServicePolicyData :: SecurityServiceType -> SecurityServicePolicyData

--   group.

--   <a>statelessRuleGroup_priority</a> - The priority of the rule group.
--   Network Firewall evaluates the stateless rule groups in a firewall
--   policy starting from the lowest priority setting.

newStatelessRuleGroup :: StatelessRuleGroup

-- | A collection of key:value pairs associated with an Amazon Web Services
--   resource. The key:value pair can be anything you define. Typically,
--   the tag key represents a category (such as "environment") and the tag
--   value represents a specific value within that category (such as
--   "test," "development," or "production"). You can add up to 50 tags to
--   each Amazon Web Services resource.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTag</a> smart constructor.
data Tag
Tag' :: Text -> Text -> Tag

-- | Create a value of <a>Tag</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:Tag'</a>, <a>tag_key</a> - Part of the key:value pair that
--   defines a tag. You can use a tag key to describe a category of
--   information, such as "customer." Tag keys are case-sensitive.
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:Tag'</a>, <a>tag_value</a> - Part of the key:value pair
--   that defines a tag. You can use a tag value to describe a specific
--   value within a category, such as "companyA" or "companyB." Tag values
--   are case-sensitive.
newTag :: Text -> Text -> Tag

-- | Violations for a resource based on the specified Firewall Manager
--   policy and Amazon Web Services account.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newViolationDetail</a> smart constructor.
data ViolationDetail
ViolationDetail' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> [ResourceViolation] -> ViolationDetail

-- | Create a value of <a>ViolationDetail</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceDescription:ViolationDetail'</a>,
--   <a>violationDetail_resourceDescription</a> - Brief description for the
--   requested resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceTags:ViolationDetail'</a>,
--   <a>violationDetail_resourceTags</a> - The <tt>ResourceTag</tt> objects
--   associated with the resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyId:ViolationDetail'</a>, <a>violationDetail_policyId</a>
--   - The ID of the Firewall Manager policy that the violation details
--   were requested for.
--   
--   <a>$sel:memberAccount:ViolationDetail'</a>,
--   <a>violationDetail_memberAccount</a> - The Amazon Web Services account
--   that the violation details were requested for.

--   details were requested for.

--   <a>violationDetail_resourceType</a> - The resource type that the
--   violation details were requested for.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceViolations:ViolationDetail'</a>,
--   <a>violationDetail_resourceViolations</a> - List of violations for the
--   requested resource.
newViolationDetail :: Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> ViolationDetail
